Posts.Content: Hi Westiegirl, I was diagnosed in march with s positive indication in 1 nude. Both my surgeon and oncologist recommended a total clearance but after doing some research I decided I didn't want this. As a result I had neo adjuvant chemo which has meant a total pathological response by my affected node (no sign of cancer now) and so I had a sentinel node biopsy on Thurs (4 nodes removed). The more I looked in to it the more I felt a total clearance was over treating. I agree with others that although NICE guidance still recommends that it seems very likely to change. Even if I hadn't had such a positive response to the chemo I still would have gone fir the SNB instead of the clearance.  Im 50 with 2 kids and the risk of lymphodaema was just too great (30%). This us reduced to 3% with SNB and so far all feels well. Do some research but the direction of axillary node treatment is changing.  Good luck

Posts.Content: Hi,  I was diagnosed with stage 3 BC in March. A biopsy on an enlarged lymph node was also positive. I was told I would have an axillary node clearance as this is still the NICE guidance, however I don't want a total clearance if only 1 node is affected. Posts.Title: Choosing not to have axillary node clearance

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah, I had a lymph biopsy early on so I knew I had at least one node involved before surgery. No others showed up on any scans and after my chemo there was no indication of any cancer on my scan, that’s why I decided not to have the clearance. They call what I had a sentinel node biopsy even though it wasn’t used to identify cancer, just to remove the affected node. They took 4 to try to make sure they got the one involved. Unfortunately for me they can’t be sure they got the affected node as the clip inserted before chemo wasn’t found, and there was no sign that any of the nodes removed had ever had cancer. I have still made the decision not to have a clearance, which is what has been recommended  but now have to decide whether to have radiotherapy to my lymph and lower neck. Again I’m reluctant as I’m feeling very positive about the treatment I’ve had so far, but it’s something I will have to consider. I’m actually at the hospital now waiting to get my CT scan prior to radiotherapy so will have to make my mind up soon.  These decisions are really difficult, I hope you can come to a decision you feel comfortable with. Good luck x
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona,  Have you had a scan following your chemo? I ask because your situation sounds very similar to mine and I chose not to have an axillary node clearance. My chemo was very effective (complete pathological response in my lymph) and so I chose to have a sentinel node biopsy to remove only the lymph nodes that were affected by the chemo. I was also very concerned about lymphodaema and so did some research and found that there is a School of thought that an ANC in some patients is overtreating. I know everyone is different, and I would never suggest you chose one course of action over another, but it may be worth speaking to your oncologist/surgeon. The ANC is a belt and braces/very risk averse decision and I didn’t feel that in my particular case it was necessary. I have been offered radiotherapy on my armpit, but as this also increases the risk of lymphodaema I have decided not to go for that either. I was told with ANC there is a 30% chance if some form of lymphodaema (from very mild to serious) which is reduced to 3% with a SNB. Whatever you decide, I hope your treatment and surgery goes well. Merry Christmas x

Posts.Content: Hi, I was diagnosed in march and had some lymph involvement. Have you had chemo? I did some research and chose not to have a full clearance, although this is still the current guidance.  I had neo adjuvant chemo and had a complete pathological response in my lymph area (no cancer found after chemo) and my breast lump had shrunk from 3.5 cms to 0.5mm so a negligible size which was removed in October. I had a SNB which removed the first 4 draining nodes. I'm also on herceptin injections for a year. I feel confident that the treatment I have had so far is sufficient and anything more would be overtreating and risk averse. Now clearly, our circumstances may be very different, and as I say, the guidance is still to have a clearance, but I just wanted to mention that there is a growing school of thought that a blanket instruction to do an axillary node clearance in all cases may be unnecessary. You may want to chat to your medical team, or have a look online.  If not, and you chose to have the clearance, I hope it goes well and your NY celebrations aren't delayed by too much x

Posts.Content: Hi Booth, My understanding is that you shouldn't need chemo for DCIS. Chemo is a systemic treatment-in case any of the little buggers are floating around elsewhere-DCIS, as per the name only affects the breast ducts, it doesn't wander. You will have the lump removed and radiotherapy to make sure there's none lurking in the ducts (this is info I received following my dcis diagnosis). I also had a cancerous lump so had to have chemo, but tbh, it was far less traumatic than I thought it would be. Not fun, inconvenient, tiring, but not what it once was. I had my therapeutic mamoplasty on Thursday (lump removed plus reconstruction) plus a matching reduction on the other side, and so far that has also been much easier to manage than I thought.  I really hope it works out and try (easier said than done) not to worry too much.
